basics.name: Steven Dillmann
basics.label: PhD Student @ Stanford
basics.summary: PhD Student at Stanford University working on AI for Science

education.institution: University of Cambridge, St John's College
education.thesis: Deep Learning for the Detection of Gravitational Waves (97%)
Representation Learning for X-ray Transient Discovery (90%)

visiting.summary: Master's thesis research on `representation learning for X-ray transient discovery` as a visiting researcher at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Summer intern research on `identifying Martian clouds with machine learning` as a visiting researcher at Caltech and NASA JPL

work.name: Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton University
work.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

conferences.name: Reviewer for Open Conference of AI Agents for Science 2025

workshops.name: Reviewer for Machine Learning and the Physical Sciences (NeurIPS 2025 Workshop)

awards.title: Head of Department Award
awards.summary: Graduating student of greatest overall merit in Aerospace Engineering at Imperial College London

awards.title: Best Computational Thesis Award
awards.awarder: Imperial College London, Department of Aeronautics
awards.summary: Student of greatest merit in a computational Master's thesis in the Department of Aeronautics at Imperial College London

awards.title: Turing Scheme Award
awards.summary: Master's thesis abroad and visiting research at Harvard University, funded by the UK government

awards.title: Engineers in Business Fellowship
awards.awarder: Engineers in Business Fellowship / Imperial Business School
awards.summary: First prize (£1000) for the healthy food business idea 'OATOMAT' at the Imperial College Business School

awards.title: Engineering Leaders Scholarship
awards.summary: Most prestigious UK engineering undergraduate scholarship for students who display the potential to become leaders and innovators in STEM, awarded by the Royal Academy of Engineering

awards.title: Bronze Excellence Award in Aeronautics
awards.awarder: Imperial College London, Department of Aeronautics
awards.summary: Third best-performing student in Aerospace Engineering at Imperial College London in Year 3

awards.title: Silver Excellence Award in Aeronautics
awards.awarder: Imperial College London, Department of Aeronautics
awards.summary: Second best-performing student in Aerospace Engineering at Imperial College London in Year 2

awards.title: Aeronautics Scholar
awards.awarder: Imperial College London, Department of Aeronautics
awards.summary: Excellent performance in Aerospace Engineering at Imperial College London across Year 1 and 2

awards.summary: Award to the top ~200 students of the German state of Baden-Württemberg in physics, mathematics, engineering, and computer science

awards.title: DMV Abitur Award
awards.summary: Best-performing graduating student of the high school in mathematics

awards.title: GDCh Abitur Award
awards.summary: Best-performing graduating student of the high school in chemistry

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
